body:
Doing a tiny bit more digging, it seems that it works okay when running in a `bash` shell for some reason?

e.g. `node -p 'process.cwd()'` succeeds when run in bash but not in zsh.

I've been trying to replicate this using ubuntu 19.10 with zsh and it is stubbornly refusing to go wrong!

Which kernel are you using? I'm using `5.3.0-42-generic` with zsh 5.7.1-1ubuntu2.

Can you strace your C program going wrong for me?

Is there anything else about your system which is unusual?

Kernel on main machine is: `5.3.0-45-generic`
Also affects my other machine which is: `5.3.0-42-generic`

Only thing I can thing of in common between the machines that might be significant is they both have LUKS encrypted file systems.

Here's an `strace` of `cwd`:

[out.log](https://github.com/rclone/rclone/files/4423923/out.log)

> Kernel on main machine is: `5.3.0-45-generic`
> Also affects my other machine which is: `5.3.0-42-generic`

My machine is `5.3.0-42-generic` and is also running on LUKS encrypted file system.

What about zsh version?

Do you have lots of stuff in your zsh rc?

I'm starting a zsh from bash by typing zsh - is that OK?

Maybe you could try reproducing this in an ubuntu VM image I can download too?

> What about zsh version?

zsh 5.7.1 (x86_64-ubuntu-linux-gnu)

> Do you have lots of stuff in your zsh rc?

Yes, but it also happens when running `zsh -f` which doesn't load them.

> I'm starting a zsh from bash by typing zsh - is that OK?

I'm not sure, but doing a bit of investigation, the directory in when switching from `zsh` to `bash` matters:

(Both of these examples behave the same when using shell replacement via `exec bash`, rather than subshell).

This fails:

```
zsh> cd ~/nextcloud/Documents/
zsh> bash
bash> cwd
getcwd() error: No such file or directory
```

But this doesn't:

```
zsh> bash
bash> cd ~/nextcloud/Documents/
bash> cwd
/home/jamesernator/nextcloud/Documents/
```

> Maybe you could try reproducing this in an ubuntu VM image I can download too?

Tried creating a VM, but the issue didn't seem to happen. If you want I can create a user for you on my machine.

OK I managed to replicate that :-)

It seems that starting the shell in the subdirectory of an `rclone mount` is the critical part. It goes wrong with`bash` and `zsh` for me like that.

```
$ cd /mnt/tmp/sub/
bash
$ ~/Rclone/pwd
getcwd() error: No such file or directory
$ /bin/pwd
/
```

pwd is the little C program you made. However this does work with `/bin/pwd`

Looking at the strace of `/bin/pwd` you can see it gets the same ENOENT from `getcwd`

However it then appears to do a workaround which involves listing `..` and finding the current directory in it.

```
getcwd(0x5612436a6500, 4096)            = -1 ENOENT (No such file or directory)
lstat("/", {st_mode=S_IFDIR|0755, st_size=4096, ...}) = 0
stat(".", {st_mode=S_IFDIR|0775, st_size=0, ...}) = 0
openat(AT_FDCWD, "..", O_RDONLY|O_NONBLOCK|O_CLOEXEC|O_DIRECTORY) = 3
fstat(3, {st_mode=S_IFDIR|0775, st_size=0, ...}) = 0
fchdir(3)                               = 0
fstat(3, {st_mode=S_IFDIR|0775, st_size=0, ...}) = 0
getdents64(3, /* 10 entries */, 32768)  = 304
close(3)                                = 0
openat(AT_FDCWD, "..", O_RDONLY|O_NONBLOCK|O_CLOEXEC|O_DIRECTORY) = 3
fstat(3, {st_mode=S_IFDIR|0755, st_size=4096, ...}) = 0
fchdir(3)                               = 0
fstat(3, {st_mode=S_IFDIR|0755, st_size=4096, ...}) = 0
getdents64(3, /* 8 entries */, 32768)   = 216
lstat("data", {st_mode=S_IFDIR|0755, st_size=4096, ...}) = 0
[snip]
lstat("tmp", {st_mode=S_IFDIR|0775, st_size=0, ...}) = 0
close(3)                                = 0
openat(AT_FDCWD, "..", O_RDONLY|O_NONBLOCK|O_CLOEXEC|O_DIRECTORY) = 3
fstat(3, {st_mode=S_IFDIR|0755, st_size=4096, ...}) = 0
fchdir(3)                               = 0
fstat(3, {st_mode=S_IFDIR|0755, st_size=4096, ...}) = 0
getdents64(3, /* 35 entries */, 32768)  = 944
close(3)                                = 0
fstat(1, {st_mode=S_IFCHR|0620, st_rdev=makedev(0x88, 0x23), ...}) = 0
write(1, "/mnt/tmp/sub\n", 13)          = 13
```

I tried this with `rclone cmount` which is a version of rclone mount which uses libfuse and this did **not** go wrong!

There is a clue here... from within the subdirectory of the freshly started bash I get this - no `.` or `..` entries.

```
$ ls -la
total 0
```

In fact they seem to be missing for all the directories :confused: 

Checking old versions of rclone I see they have never had `.` or `..`

I tried adding `.` and `..` entries and it didn't make any difference!

I think the problem comes from here

```
$ ls -l /proc/self/cwd
lrwxrwxrwx 1 ncw ncw 0 Apr 10 16:28 /proc/self/cwd -> '/mnt/tmp/sub (deleted)'
```

Why does the kernel think `/mnt/tmp/sub` is deleted?

I think this little sequence sums it up

```
$ cd /mnt/tmp/sub/
$ ls -l /proc/self/cwd
lrwxrwxrwx 1 ncw ncw 0 Apr 10 16:33 /proc/self/cwd -> /mnt/tmp/sub
$ bash
$ ls -l /proc/self/cwd
lrwxrwxrwx 1 ncw ncw 0 Apr 10 16:33 /proc/self/cwd -> '/mnt/tmp/sub (deleted)'
```

I tried increasing the `--attr-timeout 10s` and then the `ls -l /proc/self/cwd` worked for 10s then started failing as did the pwd.c code. So the kernel appears to think the directory had been deleted when it drops out of the attribute cache.

Maybe I'm supplying a wrong parameter or maybe it is a bug in the kernel...

I am experiencing the same issues right now. On Ubuntu 18.04

Kernel: 4.15.0-74-generic #84-Ubuntu SMP Thu Dec 19 08:06:28 UTC 2019 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux

I was confused why my dolphin randomly assumed directories to be deleted and some python scripts failing in subdirectories with a cwd call. Looks pretty much like the issue in question, but on an older kernel.

I also tried v1.48 and got the same behavior.

This can be even triggered by simply opening the file with nano from a subdirectory. Nano tries to create a .swp file which is not successfully written by nano. Odd, did not notice this issue before. =/

Hmm, I wonder if this was caused by a kernel change. 4.15 is quite old though.

Does adding `--attr-timeout 10s` make it work for 10 seconds?

Edit: False alarm. It randomly worked… now it doesn't. I am confused. I need to debug this more.

Edit2: Okay, super wired. Today I wanted to re-check if the --attr-timeout 10s option influence it. But when I first mounted it, everything worked like a charm. No issues whatsoever. I was using the master version and happily announced here that master has it already fixed.

Then I tried bisecting it. The old version showed the flawed behavior. Reverted to the latest master version - and it was still broken! :-(

I am not able to get it to work again correctly. I cannot think of anything I changed. Which could mean it is some wired fuse bug that triggers only if certain state of caches or kernel things… which would be a PITA to debug.

At least I can confirm that --attr-timeout 10s does delay the issue by 10 seconds.

Edit4: I tested using nano which fails to save and only leaves a temporary file. But instead of node, I made a python test-script that shows the same behaviour: 
```
import os
print(os.getcwd())
```

For fun's sake: 'Linux pine64 5.4.28-sunxi64 #20.02.7 SMP Sat Mar 28 17:25:10 CET 2020 aarch64 aarch64 aarch64 GNU/Linux' shows the same behavior. I'll try playing around with libfuse and keep up this monologue here.

Edit5: Ubuntu 16.04, kernel 4.4.0-173-generic, fuse 2.9.4 same issue as on the other system with fuse 2.9.7.

I just realized: triggering the issue with 'cd mountpoint/subdir1/ ; nano test.txt' causes only the .test.txt.swp file being saved in the subdir1. But test.txt actually is created in 'mountpoint'. Not sure if this is a fallback of nano if it is unable to save in the current directory or if it indicates anything about the issue.

Hmm, I think I might need to ask a proper file system developer for help here! I think the solution is something to do with the attribute timeouts on the inodes and invalidating them properly but I'm a bit out of my depth here!
Hi there, is there any news on this? We have the same issue when trying to use `rclone mount` to use a remote s3/webdav endpoint as a home directory for jupyter notebook.

issue.title: Current directory disappears after attr timeout expires

repository.name: fuse
repository.description: FUSE library for Go.   go get bazil.org/fuse

issue.body:
An rclone user discovered that getcwd() fails in subdirectories of rclone mounts https://github.com/rclone/rclone/issues/4104

I've managed to track this down a bit more precisely.

To reproduce with rclone first mount a local directory

```
mkdir -p /tmp/src/sub
rclone mount /tmp/src /mnt/tmp
```

In another window

```
$ cd /mnt/tmp/sub ; ls -l /proc/self/cwd
lrwxrwxrwx 1 ncw ncw 0 Apr 29 15:55 /proc/self/cwd -> /mnt/tmp/sub
$
$ # wait a few seconds
$ ls -l /proc/self/cwd
rwxrwxrwx 1 ncw ncw 0 Apr 29 15:55 /proc/self/cwd -> '/mnt/tmp/sub (deleted)'
```

`/proc/self/cwd` being deleted means that for example the `getcwd()` system call fails

```
$ python -c 'import os; print os.getcwd()'
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<string>", line 1, in <module>
OSError: [Errno 2] No such file or directory
```

Rclone sets attribute timeouts of 1 second by default and if you increase the attribute timeout (with `--attr-timeout`) then the current working directory lasts for longer so it is related to that attribute timeout.

Rclone has a another mount command (you compile it using `--tags cmount`) using libfuse and this does **not** have the same problem which is puzzling, making me think it is something that this library is doing, or maybe something extra that libfuse does.

I could fix this by increasing the attribute timeout (maybe just for directories) but I don't want to make it very large otherwise changes won't be noticed.

Any ideas or suggestions much appreciated - thanks!

body:
I haven't figured out what is going on yet...

I submitted https://github.com/bazil/fuse/issues/250 in the hope that someone more knowledgeable about FUSE internals might help :-)

A massive thank you to @tv42 who has worked out what is going on! See bazil/fuse#250 for the full explanation.

It turned out to be a problem in rclone. It was sending different nodes to the fuse layer with the same information in which caused fuse to believe that the directory had been deleted and re-created. This was fixed by caching the actual node for an item and returning that.

Please have a go with this and tell me what you think.

https://beta.rclone.org/branch/v1.51.0-264-g2696e369-fix-4104-cwd-disappears-beta/ (uploaded in 15-30 mins)

I can confirm that at least for our use case everything is working with that fix. 
E.g. python os.getcwd and also git clone that wasn't working before from within a mounted folder, now are ok.
Thanks a lot @ncw!
@ncw Could this also be the cause of the memory leaks related to `--attr-timeout`, when set to 0, or is that still a different issue?

@dciangot thanks for testing

@darthShadow yes that crossed my mind too... Fancy giving it a test?
